figure.name: Entity terms

term.name: biological entity
term.definition: material entity ( REF idC941C5B14FFB4aecAA18427AF3D1435A ) that was or is a living organism

term.name: entity
term.definition: concrete or abstract thing that exists, did exist, or might exist, including associations among these things
term.example: A person, object, event, idea, process, etc.

term.name: immaterial entity
term.definition: entity ( REF id040D6A1B412A4cc6921882357A58F747 ) that does not occupy three-dimensional space
term.example: Idea, process, organization, etc.

term.name: material entity
term.definition: entity ( REF id040D6A1B412A4cc6921882357A58F747 ) that occupies three-dimensional space
term.note: All material entities have certain characteristics that can be described and therefore this concept is important for ontology purposes.

term.name: non-biological entity
term.definition: material entity ( REF idC941C5B14FFB4aecAA18427AF3D1435A ) that is not and has never been a living organism

term.name: person
term.definition: biological entity ( REF idBFF7F45423994d21BDE8FD5BEE09F6FD ) that is a human being
term.source: ISO/IEC TS29003:2018, 3.12, modified to add reference to biological entity definition

figure.name: General system terms

term.name: cooperative ITS
term.definition: subset of ITS ( REF id95C4A86465B74046823106670EF95C77 ) where information is shared among ITS stations ( REF idF1E402D380EE478c957A2FF53D9EA0C5 ) in a manner that enables its use by multiple ITS services ( REF id4D485872E9EE414e9CE1AB855A03540B )

term.name: intelligent transport system
term.definition: system ( REF id9F9DE40282B84b8aAD4F618C7836F09E ) comprised of information, communication, sensor, and control technologies and that is designed to benefit a surface transport system ( REF id261629D58D7B439b8DAE5905D2EEF4D5 )
term.note: There is not complete agreement on the precise limits of ITS. Currently, the term is almost exclusively applied to ground-based travel of goods and people over significant distances. The term is viewed as including ferry systems, which often form an integral part of a local surface transport system; it is less clear if it includes long-distance sea-fairing ships. ITS is also generally applied to transport systems that cover a considerable distance (e.g., control systems for factory conveyance technologies are not often referred to as "ITS"). Some have suggested that air travel, which is arguably a transport system designed to move physical entities between points on the surface of the earth, should be included in the scope of the term, but this perspective is not universally accepted. It is expected that the exact limits of the term will be further refined as the technology matures.
"Intelligent transportation system" is the American English equivalent.
Benefits potentially include, but are not limited to, increased safety, sustainability, efficiency, and comfort.

The long form (i.e., "intelligent transport system") is often used when the noun is used as a subject, whereas the abbreviation (i.e., "ITS") is often used to modify another noun (e.g., "Intelligent transport systems provide ITS services.").

term.name: surface transport system
term.definition: transport system ( REF id8648D088383A40a19D19B3E02A7060DF ) designed to move material entities ( REF idC941C5B14FFB4aecAA18427AF3D1435A ) across the surface or near-surface of the Earth
term.note: A surface transport system might include tunnels, bridges, and similar elements.

term.name: system
term.definition: combination of interacting elements organized to achieve one or more stated purposes

term.name: transport system
term.definition: system ( REF id9F9DE40282B84b8aAD4F618C7836F09E ) of infrastructure elements and optionally vehicles ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) that jointly are designed to move material entities ( REF idC941C5B14FFB4aecAA18427AF3D1435A ) from an origin to a destination
term.note: Transport systems can also include any supporting system, such as information and control systems.

figure.name: General architecture terms

term.name: architecture
term.definition: <system> fundamental concepts or properties of a system in its environment ( REF idBCD10BE481B544698858512B057E1D40 ) embodied in its elements ( REF idA9454DB86F4C47c9902B7ABEE2462EA8 ), relationships, and in the principles of its design and evolution

term.name: architecture description
term.definition: work product used to express an architecture ( REF id1977CCC04EA948719638C89546E52E47 )

term.name: architecture framework
term.definition: conventions, principles and practices for the description of architectures ( REF id1977CCC04EA948719638C89546E52E47 ) established within a specific domain of application and/or community of stakeholders
term.example: Generalised Enterprise Reference Architecture and Methodologies (GERAM) [ISO 15704] is an architecture framework.
Reference Model of Open Distributed Processing (RM-ODP) [ISO/IEC 10746] is an architecture framework.

term.name: architecture model
term.definition: work product representing one or more architecture views ( REF idBD7658051DA3495bA45E71D438FCD3DF ) and expressed in a format governed by a model kind ( REF id539D69676C04491081CB654FB9B87320 )

term.name: architecture view
term.definition: work product expressing the architecture ( REF id1977CCC04EA948719638C89546E52E47 ) of a system ( REF id9F9DE40282B84b8aAD4F618C7836F09E ) from the perspective of specific system concerns ( REF idFA25496536F542ee8EEECAE2225A828E )

term.name: architecture viewpoint
term.definition: work product establishing the conventions for the construction, interpretation and use of architecture views ( REF idBD7658051DA3495bA45E71D438FCD3DF ) to frame specific system concerns ( REF idFA25496536F542ee8EEECAE2225A828E )

term.name: concern
term.definition: <system> interest in a system ( REF id9F9DE40282B84b8aAD4F618C7836F09E ) relevant to one or more of its stakeholders ( REF id730A631B2F0A43c2870FF7EC89013DA2 )
term.note: A concern pertains to any influence on a system in its environment, including developmental, technological, business, operational, organizational, political, economic, legal, regulatory, ecological and social influences.

term.name: element
term.definition: <architecture> component member of an architecture model ( REF idBFAAF75FCA1C4aaeB62F1F827303C22F ) included in an architecture view ( REF idBD7658051DA3495bA45E71D438FCD3DF )

term.name: environment
term.definition: <system> context determining the setting and circumstances of all influences upon a system ( REF id9F9DE40282B84b8aAD4F618C7836F09E )
term.note: The environment of a system includes developmental, technological, business, operational, organizational, political, economic, legal, regulatory, ecological and social influences.

term.name: model kind
term.definition: conventions for a type of modelling
term.note: Examples of model kinds include data flow diagrams, class diagrams, Petri nets, balance sheets, organization charts and state transition models.

term.name: stakeholder
term.definition: <system> individual, team, organization, or classes thereof, having an interest in a system ( REF id9F9DE40282B84b8aAD4F618C7836F09E )

figure.name: Architecture view terms

term.name: communications view
term.definition: architecture view ( REF idBD7658051DA3495bA45E71D438FCD3DF ) from the communications viewpoint ( REF idFA802A0C473248fc9F50178DD38C56D8 )
term.note: Within ITS, the preferred model for describing the communications view is based on the ITS-S reference architecture.

term.name: communications viewpoint
term.definition: architecture viewpoint ( REF id2D6E2A89A52E4a689CD868265F24A29E ) used to frame concerns related to all layers of the OSI stack and related management and security issues

term.name: enterprise view
term.definition: architecture view ( REF idBD7658051DA3495bA45E71D438FCD3DF ) from the enterprise viewpoint ( REF idF107015E884048deAC7C651CBC4B8420 )

term.name: enterprise viewpoint
term.definition: architecture viewpoint ( REF id2D6E2A89A52E4a689CD868265F24A29E ) used to frame the policies, funding incentives, working arrangements, and jurisdictional structure that support the technical layers of the architecture

term.name: functional view
term.definition: architecture view ( REF idBD7658051DA3495bA45E71D438FCD3DF ) from the functional viewpoint ( REF id44BCE17E4D7F4e10AEBDA4BEA9679B0E )

term.name: functional viewpoint
term.definition: architecture viewpoint ( REF id2D6E2A89A52E4a689CD868265F24A29E ) used to frame concerns related to the definition of processes that perform surface transport functions and data flows shared between these processes

term.name: physical view
term.definition: architecture view ( REF idBD7658051DA3495bA45E71D438FCD3DF ) from the physical viewpoint ( REF idAB7049839C6D4f60BC7472FCFED26DB4 )
term.note: The term "deployment view" is sometimes used within the broader ICT community, but the term "physical view" is preferred to prevent confusion between the physical view of a reference architecture and any part of a deployment architecture.

term.name: physical viewpoint
term.definition: architecture viewpoint ( REF id2D6E2A89A52E4a689CD868265F24A29E ) used to frame concerns related to the assignment of functionality to physical objects ( REF id8EA65F2D6F6347bf8FF4C5CD35C61C68 ) and the interfaces among these physical objects

figure.name: Architecture - Communication view terms

term.name: access layer
term.definition: protocol layer that contains the open systems interconnect (OSI) physical and data link layer protocols

term.name: application entity
term.definition: <ITS-S> part of the ITS station reference architecture ( REF idCAC31494A311430cBB567F2A82C166EC ) that is responsible for providing ITS-related functionality
term.note: Within the US, the NTCIP standards identify an "information layer" on top of the traditional OSI stack; however, the purpose of this layer includes both information configuration and functionality. The ITS-S reference architecture separates these two roles between the management entity and the application entity.

term.name: facilities layer
term.definition: <ITS-S> protocol layer in the ITS station reference architecture ( REF idCAC31494A311430cBB567F2A82C166EC ) containing the open systems interconnect (OSI) session, presentation, and application layer protocols
term.note: Within the US, the NTCIP standards call the facilities layer the "application layer"; however, as this term is easily confused with both the OSI application layer and the application entity, the term should be avoided and qualified when used (e.g., OSI application layer).

term.name: ITS-S access layer
term.definition: <ITS-S> protocol layer in the ITS station reference architecture ( REF idCAC31494A311430cBB567F2A82C166EC ) containing the open systems interconnect (OSI) physical and data link layer protocols for ITS communications
term.note: Within the IETF, the term "link layer" is used to describe the same functionality as the ITS-S access layer.
Within the US, the NTCIP standards use the term "subnet layer" to describe the same functionality as the ITS-S access layer.

term.name: management entity
term.definition: <ITS-S> part of the ITS station reference architecture ( REF idCAC31494A311430cBB567F2A82C166EC ) that is responsible for management of communications and configuration information for the local physical object ( REF id8EA65F2D6F6347bf8FF4C5CD35C61C68 ) and possibly remote physical objects

term.name: security entity
term.definition: <ITS-S> part of the ITS station reference architecture ( REF idCAC31494A311430cBB567F2A82C166EC ) that is responsible for providing privacy, communication security, and system security

term.name: transnet layer
term.definition: <ITS-S> protocol layer in the ITS station reference architecture ( REF idCAC31494A311430cBB567F2A82C166EC ) containing the open systems interconnect (OSI) network and transport layer protocols
term.note: The full name of this layer is the networking and transport layer, but the term transnet layer provides a more concise name.

figure.name: Architecture - Enterprise view terms

term.name: document
term.definition: uniquely identified unit of information for human use
term.note: A document can be a single information item, or part of a larger information item.
term.example: A report, specification, manual, or book, in printed or electronic form.

term.name: enterprise object
term.definition: element ( REF idA9454DB86F4C47c9902B7ABEE2462EA8 ) within an enterprise view ( REF id4C3EDEBD6786459a8343C1B09B870255 ) that represents an organization or individual

term.name: extends
term.definition: <enterprise view> relationship ( REF id15042ADE65AA448a98FF7ECFA044549B ) where one resource ( REF id55BD7B9720A44728AE93ED1F75D7692B ) supplements another resource
term.example: A module might extend the functionality of another module.

term.name: formal coordination
term.definition: <enterprise view> interaction ( REF id266739C36D20412dBADD84864A84FB14 ) between two enterprise objects ( REF idFE675C964126463bBB0CAB673DBFF9C7 ) governed by a documented agreement
term.example: A road operator might enter into formal agreement(s) with the owner of a road and the owner(s) of the associated roadside equipment.

term.name: includes
term.definition: <enterprise view> relationship ( REF id15042ADE65AA448a98FF7ECFA044549B ) where one resource ( REF id55BD7B9720A44728AE93ED1F75D7692B ) contains another resource
term.example: Every ITS component includes one or more modules.

term.name: informal coordination
term.definition: <enterprise view> interaction ( REF id266739C36D20412dBADD84864A84FB14 ) between two enterprise objects ( REF idFE675C964126463bBB0CAB673DBFF9C7 ) governed by an understanding that is not documented in a formal agreement between the two parties

term.name: interaction
term.definition: <enterprise view> element ( REF idA9454DB86F4C47c9902B7ABEE2462EA8 ) that represents coordination between two enterprise objects ( REF idFE675C964126463bBB0CAB673DBFF9C7 )

term.name: relationship
term.definition: <enterprise view> element ( REF idA9454DB86F4C47c9902B7ABEE2462EA8 ) that represents an association between two resources ( REF id55BD7B9720A44728AE93ED1F75D7692B )

term.name: resource
term.definition: <enterprise view> element ( REF idA9454DB86F4C47c9902B7ABEE2462EA8 ) that represents an entity that is managed, operated, referenced, and/or used to develop and provide ITS

term.name: role
term.definition: <enterprise view> element ( REF idA9454DB86F4C47c9902B7ABEE2462EA8 ) that represents the specified responsibilities between an enterprise object ( REF idFE675C964126463bBB0CAB673DBFF9C7 ) and another enterprise view element

figure.name: Architecture - Functional view terms

term.name: data flow
term.definition: representation of data flowing between two processes ( REF id6DD0743FF44F4f0e9817C766379AD954 ) or between a process and a terminator ( REF id98ACC203E1E34474AF1A04245619E6BF )

term.name: function
term.definition: <functional view> series of actions or activities performed by some object to achieve a goal
term.note: A function transforms inputs into outputs that may include the creation, modification, monitoring, or destruction of elements.
term.source: ISO 13537:2010, 3.2.4.3, revised to better conform to current ISO terminological entry format

term.name: process
term.definition: <functional view> series of one or more functions in support of an ITS service ( REF id4D485872E9EE414e9CE1AB855A03540B )

term.name: process specification
term.definition: document ( REF id4D42D0BA04584798BEB7CFD665901F33 ) that defines a lowest-level process ( REF id6DD0743FF44F4f0e9817C766379AD954 )

figure.name: Architecture - Physical view terms

term.name: functional object
term.definition: set of related processes ( REF id6DD0743FF44F4f0e9817C766379AD954 ) that are performed by a physical object ( REF id8EA65F2D6F6347bf8FF4C5CD35C61C68 ) to fulfil aspects of an ITS service ( REF id4D485872E9EE414e9CE1AB855A03540B )
term.note: The term "module" is used by the European FRAME architecture while the Architecture Reference for Cooperative and Intelligent Transportation (ARC-IT) uses the term "functional object".
term.example: A vehicle OBE might include a "vehicle basic safety" functional object.

term.name: information flow
term.definition: information that is exchanged between physical objects ( REF id8EA65F2D6F6347bf8FF4C5CD35C61C68 )

term.name: information transfer
term.definition: information flow ( REF id752D601C79B54677BF47786D7FA84DBF ) from a physical object ( REF id8EA65F2D6F6347bf8FF4C5CD35C61C68 ) acting as an information provider and sent to another physical object ( REF id8EA65F2D6F6347bf8FF4C5CD35C61C68 ) acting as an information consumer
term.note: The term "information flow triple" is used extensively in the Architecture Reference for Cooperative and Intelligent Transportation (ARC-IT, http://arc-it.net).

term.name: ITS component
term.definition: physical object ( REF id3783095C41E041c8B0CC1813CBCAEE44 ) that has been assigned one or more functional objects ( REF idEC65B14A2BF845deBCC48632F635C9FF ) in the provision of one or more ITS services ( REF id4D485872E9EE414e9CE1AB855A03540B )
term.note: Physical objects are ITS components if they are an integral part of the system; otherwise they are terminators.

term.name: module
term.definition: functional object ( REF idEC65B14A2BF845deBCC48632F635C9FF ) that can be replaced and has defined interfaces

term.name: physical object
term.definition: <physical view> abstraction of a material entity ( REF idC941C5B14FFB4aecAA18427AF3D1435A ) that interacts with other abstract material entities in the provision of ITS services ( REF id4D485872E9EE414e9CE1AB855A03540B )
term.note: Physical objects are represented as elements within the physical view and perform a role. Physical objects can be implemented as cloud-based systems.
Within many ITS reference architectures, physical objects are placed into one of five categories: centre, support, field, vehicle, or traveller.

term.name: terminator
term.definition: entity ( REF id040D6A1B412A4cc6921882357A58F747 ) that is external to the ITS service ( REF id4D485872E9EE414e9CE1AB855A03540B ) implementation but with which the implementation communicates either to obtain inputs or to which it can send outputs
term.note: A terminator can exist within functional and physical views.

figure.name: Architecture type terms

term.name: deployment architecture
term.definition: architecture ( REF id1977CCC04EA948719638C89546E52E47 ) that provides a vision of a specific deployment of a system within a geographic area

term.name: ITS deployment architecture
term.definition: deployment architecture ( REF id78E7722880BD47d7BEB75B27B5842A74 ) for one or more ITS services ( REF id4D485872E9EE414e9CE1AB855A03540B )

term.name: ITS planning architecture
term.definition: planning architecture ( REF id0875724C4E4C4527A11C1B5977FA6250 ) for one or more ITS services ( REF id4D485872E9EE414e9CE1AB855A03540B )

term.name: ITS reference architecture
term.definition: reference architecture ( REF id7823F79833D54238B649F8A4D20F13C5 ) for one or more ITS services ( REF id4D485872E9EE414e9CE1AB855A03540B )
term.note: An ITS architecture might be a reference, planning, or deployment architecture.
The Harmonised Architecture Reference for Technical Standards (HARTS; http://htg7.org) is an example of an ITS reference architecture.

term.name: ITS-S reference architecture
term.definition: reference architecture ( REF id7823F79833D54238B649F8A4D20F13C5 ) for handling communications within a physical object ( REF id8EA65F2D6F6347bf8FF4C5CD35C61C68 ) as defined in ISO 21217
term.note: The ITS-S reference architecture provides a model for describing communication.

term.name: planning architecture
term.definition: architecture ( REF id1977CCC04EA948719638C89546E52E47 ) that provides a long-term vision of system elements ( REF idA9454DB86F4C47c9902B7ABEE2462EA8 ) that may be deployed and managed by different projects and/or entities within a geographic area
term.note: Some countries use the term "regional architecture", but in international standards, the term "regional" is avoided due to its multiple meanings.

term.name: reference architecture
term.definition: architecture ( REF id1977CCC04EA948719638C89546E52E47 ) that provides a template solution for planning ( REF id0875724C4E4C4527A11C1B5977FA6250 ) and deployment architectures ( REF id78E7722880BD47d7BEB75B27B5842A74 )
term.note: Interface standards are based on a reference architecture, which should be explicitly described.

figure.name: Data concept management terms

term.name: data concept
term.definition: data element ( REF id6ADFFDA7618A4047AE100991CBCE83C7 ), class ( REF idDF674EF5FB8049aaBE03DC6E5FF03853 ), value domain ( REF idACC1C171626D40479E3CC4C273BEA796 ), data frame ( REF idD0B512E1030A4b998CB13473D336CBFC ), message ( REF id7E8CF3F643284ed199FEF6FA0A1FDADC ), interface dialogue ( REF idA5ED9D410EE248389659C4C127C6159A ), or data dictionary ( REF idB06371D38EFC48e299F50E38BFECA3F5 ) defined, at a minimum, with an unambiguous identifier and a definition
term.note: In order to exchange a value corresponding to a data concept, more information than an identifier and a definition might be needed. For a property, a data type is needed. Depending on the kind of property, other data elements such as unit of measure, and language, might be needed as well. The additional information can be given in the data dictionary, in a data specification that references the data concept or associated with the data themselves.

term.name: data concept registry
term.definition: electronic data dictionary ( REF idB06371D38EFC48e299F50E38BFECA3F5 ) that follows precise documented rules for the registration and management of stored data concepts ( REF id5C989C1352B14d07BB1E631FC7D46F8F )
term.note: The data concept registry contains meta-attributes about data concepts in terms of their names and representational forms as well as the semantics associated with the data concepts. A data concept registry may contain metadata that assists information interchange and re-use, both from the perspective of human users and for machine-interpretation of data concepts.
A data registry typically includes advanced features for adding, retrieving, and working with its contents.

term.name: data dictionary
term.definition: collection of data concept ( REF id5C989C1352B14d07BB1E631FC7D46F8F ) that allows lookup by entity ( REF id040D6A1B412A4cc6921882357A58F747 ) identifier

term.name: meta-attribute
term.definition: documenting characteristic of a data concept ( REF id5C989C1352B14d07BB1E631FC7D46F8F ) that is stored in a data dictionary ( REF idB06371D38EFC48e299F50E38BFECA3F5 )

figure.name: Data concept type terms

term.name: class
term.definition: set of ideas, abstractions or things in the real world that are identified with explicit boundaries and meaning and whose properties and behaviour follow the same rules
term.note: Some TC 204 standards use the term "object class" for consistency with ISO 11179-1, but within ITS, the term "class" is more generally understood.
This is semantically equivalent to a "class" as used within UML(ISO19505-2:2012).
term.source: ISO/IEC 11179-1:2015, 3.3.18, term changed to "class" and notes added

term.name: data element
term.definition: unit of data that is considered in context to be indivisible and which includes an unambiguous representational form
term.note: A data element considered indivisible in one context (e.g., location) may be divisible in another context (e.g., latitude, longitude, and elevation).

term.name: data frame
term.definition: specific grouping of data elements ( REF id6ADFFDA7618A4047AE100991CBCE83C7 ) that describes information of interest through a useful grouping of more atomic properties about one or more classes ( REF idDF674EF5FB8049aaBE03DC6E5FF03853 )
term.note: A data frame can contain other data frames.
The grouping can be a set, sequence, or a choice.

term.name: interface dialogue
term.definition: bi-directional communication sequence between two parties in accordance with predetermined protocols
term.note: The term "dialog" represents the American English spelling.
The term "dialogue" can be used when the interface context is known.

term.name: message
term.definition: grouping of data elements ( REF id6ADFFDA7618A4047AE100991CBCE83C7 ), data frames ( REF idD0B512E1030A4b998CB13473D336CBFC ), or data elements ( REF id6ADFFDA7618A4047AE100991CBCE83C7 ) and data frames ( REF idD0B512E1030A4b998CB13473D336CBFC ) that is used to convey a complete set of information

term.name: value domain
term.definition: a set of permissible values

figure.name: System engineering terms

term.name: role
term.definition: specified responsibilities

term.name: scenario
term.definition: <use case> a description of the sequence of events from the user's perspective to perform a task in a specified context
term.source: ISO/IEC 25062:2006(en), A.17, added the context of a use case

term.name: use case
term.definition: description of the behavioural requirements of a system and its interaction with a user

figure.name: Time terms

term.name: duration
term.definition: time between two instants ( REF id150D2AD67B234518A162F2C1483BB4F8 )

term.name: instant
term.definition: zero-dimensional geographic primitive representing position in time

figure.name: Top-level physical object terms

term.name: central system
term.definition: ITS component ( REF id3783095C41E041c8B0CC1813CBCAEE44 ) that provides application, management, and/or administrative functions from a centralized location (i.e., not at the roadside ( REF id718D31DE1698436a9BA71D3F4512432A ))

term.name: field system
term.definition: infrastructure-based ITS component ( REF id3783095C41E041c8B0CC1813CBCAEE44 ) located outside of a data centre that is designed to provide local processing or routing services while stationary
term.note: Field systems can be permanently installed or transportable.
The term "roadside system" is typically used to describe field systems along a roadside but can also be used to refer to kiosks and any other systems.
Typically, field systems are located along the roadside.
Typically, the operation of a field system is governed by management functions running in a centre system.
term.example: traffic detector, camera, signal controller, message sign, tolling station

term.name: personal system
term.definition: ITS component ( REF id3783095C41E041c8B0CC1813CBCAEE44 ), other than a vehicle system ( REF id12A56C8A1EFE4cb8983C1C23C593EB84 ), that is used by a person in relation to a past, current, or upcoming journey

term.name: support system
term.definition: ITS component ( REF id3783095C41E041c8B0CC1813CBCAEE44 ) that provides services in support of one or more other ITS components
term.example: Data distribution system, network time source, cooperative ITS credentials management system

term.name: vehicle system
term.definition: ITS component ( REF id3783095C41E041c8B0CC1813CBCAEE44 ) that is installed as a component of a vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A )

figure.name: Centre physical object terms

term.name: emergency management central system
term.definition: central system ( REF id75E3C9D3F2084e00BA93F5DD34084653 ) that allows an entity to manage and respond to crashes, events, disasters, evacuation orders, and other incidents

term.name: fleet and freight management central system
term.definition: central system ( REF id75E3C9D3F2084e00BA93F5DD34084653 ) that allows a fleet or freight operator to manage and control its personnel, equipment, and/or freight
term.index: fleet and freight management central system

term.name: maintenance and construction central management system
term.definition: central system ( REF id75E3C9D3F2084e00BA93F5DD34084653 ) that allows an entity to monitor and manage the construction and maintenance of road infrastructure
term.index: maintenance and construction central management system

term.name: payment administration central system
term.definition: central system ( REF id75E3C9D3F2084e00BA93F5DD34084653 ) that allows an entity to manage financial transactions related to transportation, especially the electronic transfer of funds

term.name: public transport central management system
term.definition: central system ( REF id75E3C9D3F2084e00BA93F5DD34084653 ) that allows an entity to manage the activities of a public transport agency

term.name: traffic management central system
term.definition: central system ( REF id75E3C9D3F2084e00BA93F5DD34084653 ) that monitors and controls traffic and the road network

term.name: traffic regulation central system
term.definition: central system ( REF id75E3C9D3F2084e00BA93F5DD34084653 ) that officially records traffic regulations in electronic form so that they can be distributed to other systems

term.name: transport information central system
term.definition: central system ( REF id75E3C9D3F2084e00BA93F5DD34084653 ) that provides information of interest to the travelling public

figure.name: Field physical object terms

term.name: connected
term.definition: characteristic of a material entity ( REF idC941C5B14FFB4aecAA18427AF3D1435A ) that is equipped with enabled (i.e., on) and operational electronic communication technologies to support ITS services, including the means to send and receive data to and from other connected entities
term.note: The term "connected" does not imply support for any specific communications interface or ITS-S application process.

term.name: connected roadside equipment
term.definition: ITS roadside equipment ( REF idB6702EA11A52412eA44F00E7A7D44F40 ) that performs ITS services ( REF id4D485872E9EE414e9CE1AB855A03540B ) by exchanging electronic messages with nearby vehicle systems ( REF id12A56C8A1EFE4cb8983C1C23C593EB84 ) and/or personal systems ( REF id3237352F30AA4cbeA2A9728C0671B5A4 ) via short-range wireless technologies
term.note: Connected roadside equipment typically provides ITS-related functionality but the term includes roadside equipment that only provide the ITS service of routing for short-range ireless technologies.
The term "connected vehicle roadside equipment" is used within the current version of the Architecture Reference for Cooperative and Intelligent Transportation (ARC-IT, http://arc-it.net).

term.name: connected unit
term.definition: electronic device that is connected ( REF id49FF108A0CA140d49A439CF9BBABA1BB ) using one or more communication media

term.name: field support equipment
term.definition: portable field system ( REF idC7D0D59CB4CF482c92AAA0D821A13A05 ) used by field personnel to locally troubleshoot, initialize, reprogram, and test infrastructure equipment

term.name: ITS roadside equipment
term.definition: field system ( REF idC7D0D59CB4CF482c92AAA0D821A13A05 ) that performs localized ITS services ( REF id4D485872E9EE414e9CE1AB855A03540B )
term.note: ITS services that can be performed by ITS roadside equipment include surveillance, traffic control, information provision, payment transaction services, and/or enforcement
term.example: traffic signal controller, variable message sign, vehicle detection

term.name: roadside unit
term.definition: part of ITS connected roadside equipment ( REF id5DAF919582BA4ebcA9458826C7601B83 ) that provides wireless connectivity to vehicle systems ( REF id12A56C8A1EFE4cb8983C1C23C593EB84 ) and/or personal systems ( REF id3237352F30AA4cbeA2A9728C0671B5A4 )

figure.name: Personal physical object terms

term.name: nomadic device
term.definition: personal information device ( REF id3E33A4D7FC4341d981D249AC28E47690 ) that is taken with and can be accessed by the traveller during a journey

term.name: nomadic vehicle device
term.definition: personal system ( REF id3237352F30AA4cbeA2A9728C0671B5A4 ) consisting of global navigation satellite system (GNSS) receiver and/or wireless modules that are connected to a vehicle during a trip

term.name: personal information device
term.definition: personal system ( REF id3237352F30AA4cbeA2A9728C0671B5A4 ) that enables personal access to traveller information
term.example: personal computer

term.name: public information device
term.definition: personal system ( REF id3237352F30AA4cbeA2A9728C0671B5A4 ) that provides public access to traveller information
term.example: kiosk

figure.name: Support physical object terms

term.name: cooperative ITS credentials management system
term.definition: support system ( REF id23E6CD14703145869348FF4FB599A887 ) that enables trusted communications among ITS components and protects data from unauthorized access

term.name: map provision system
term.definition: support system ( REF id23E6CD14703145869348FF4FB599A887 ) that provides map databases used to support ITS services ( REF id4D485872E9EE414e9CE1AB855A03540B )
term.note: The exact term for this concept might change in the next version of this document.

figure.name: Vehicle physical object terms

term.name: ITS on-board equipment
term.definition: vehicle system ( REF id12A56C8A1EFE4cb8983C1C23C593EB84 ) that provides all ITS functionality on-board the vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A )
term.note: ITS on-board equipment relates to any functionality. When there is a need to distinguish between core functionality and that by a special vehicle, the term can be further refined by indicating the type of vehicle to which the on-board equipment relates. For example, emergency vehicle on-board equipment can provide specialized functionality.
The on-board equipment may also perform other functions.

term.name: ITS on-board unit
term.definition: part of on-board equipment ( REF id19370BF79EB84485AEAD2DDF5F784F2F ) that provides wireless connectivity to other ITS components ( REF id3783095C41E041c8B0CC1813CBCAEE44 ) external to the vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A )
term.note: An OBU implementation can also include ITS functionality.

figure.name: ITS station terms

term.name: bounded secured managed domain
term.definition: abstract entity representing a managed processing and memory environment that provides protection from code and data that has not been determined to meet established security requirements

term.name: functionality
term.definition: <normal English meaning>

term.name: ITS station
term.definition: bounded secured managed domain ( REF id866BE3730A304564BBC18CA138D01808 ) that is able to meet requirements of the ITS trust domain ( REF id9A44E9204B4D46caAAE8F28547675FDE ) within which it wishes to participate
term.note: The ITS station reference architecture is defined in ISO 21217.

term.name: ITS trust domain
term.definition: set of bounded secured managed domains ( REF id866BE3730A304564BBC18CA138D01808 ) that meet a defined set of ITS industry security requirements

term.name: ITS-S communication unit
term.definition: physical unit in an ITS-SU ( REF id32A3B8B6410142fd9540A71FEF5521A5 ) containing part or all of the functionality of an ITS-S ( REF idF1E402D380EE478c957A2FF53D9EA0C5 )

term.name: ITS-S host
term.definition: functionalities ( REF id6593BC0CD60B42fbB46A55ACB3DFB56B ) in an ITS-S node ( REF id97580DA2960B420cAFA27BD0EAF104FC ) other than the functionalities of an ITS-S router ( REF idDBBB2A22A7F04e468238D737A4612729 ), ITS-S border router, ITS-S mobile router, or an ITS-S gateway
term.note: ITS-S border router and ITS-S mobile router are ITS-S routers with added functionality, which is why they are separately excluded from the above definition.
ITS-S border router, ITS-S mobile router, and ITS-S gateway are defined in ISO 21217.
This is a refinement of the original definition contained in ISO 21217.

term.name: ITS-S node
term.definition: node comprised of a set of functionalities in an ITS-S unit ( REF id32A3B8B6410142fd9540A71FEF5521A5 ) that is connected to the ITS station ( REF idF1E402D380EE478c957A2FF53D9EA0C5 ) internal network or comprises an entire ITS-S unit

term.name: ITS-S router
term.definition: functionalities ( REF id6593BC0CD60B42fbB46A55ACB3DFB56B ) in an ITS-S node ( REF id97580DA2960B420cAFA27BD0EAF104FC ) that enable connecting two networks and forwarding packets not explicitly addressed to the ITS-S node
term.note: This is a refinement of the original definition contained in ISO 21217.

term.name: ITS-S unit
term.definition: instantiation of an ITS station ( REF idF1E402D380EE478c957A2FF53D9EA0C5 )

figure.name: ITS application terms

term.name: interoperability design
term.definition: characteristics necessary to fully define how various physical objects ( REF id8EA65F2D6F6347bf8FF4C5CD35C61C68 ) interoperate to provide a service ( REF id1C826F4DC7744eb7B8DDB33EF68A28F5 )
term.note: Characteristics often include but are not limited to functional, performance, and interface requirements.

term.name: ITS application
term.definition: realization of an ITS service ( REF id4D485872E9EE414e9CE1AB855A03540B ) that involves an association of two or more complementary ITS-S application processes ( REF id371D609484264a3598C7092967DD21DD )

term.name: ITS application specification
term.definition: one or more documents that detail the interoperability design ( REF id573047514B814efe85FCFA271736EE72 ) for an ITS application ( REF id1A22C407CEBA41c495E1D89FC4C87504 )

term.name: ITS application template
term.definition: defined annotated outline for an ITS application specification ( REF id4D636FF9C4F84e41B76850FC248B4D99 )

term.name: ITS deployment
term.definition: installation capable of performing one or more ITS applications ( REF id1A22C407CEBA41c495E1D89FC4C87504 )
term.note: An ITS deployment typically refers to the support, central and roadside ITS stations coupled with a tacit acknowledgement of the mobile ITS stations that will communicate with the support, central, or roadside ITS stations.

term.name: ITS implementation
term.definition: integration of each physical object ( REF id8EA65F2D6F6347bf8FF4C5CD35C61C68 ) necessary to implement one or more ITS applications ( REF id1A22C407CEBA41c495E1D89FC4C87504 )
term.note: An ITS application typically requires multiple components (e.g., an ITS-S acting as a user and another ITS-S acting as a provider). An ITS implementation includes a sample of each component necessary for the service but often does not represent a complete deployment.
An ITS implementation is typically used for a laboratory or other experimental environment prior to a full-scale deployment.

figure.name: ITS-S application process terms

term.name: ITS application role
term.definition: ITS-S user need ( REF idAE2F5ED40F9549e2A07B4C547A3C4CF4 ) expressed as a formal set of interoperability requirements that need to be fulfilled to satisfy a portion of functionality of an ITS application ( REF id1A22C407CEBA41c495E1D89FC4C87504 )

term.name: ITS-S application
term.definition: ITS-S application process ( REF id371D609484264a3598C7092967DD21DD ) residing in the application entity ( REF idB67D64896F6943cc98608CF4BB934A7D )

term.name: ITS-S application implementation
term.definition: implementation of an ITS-S application process ( REF id371D609484264a3598C7092967DD21DD ) within the application entity ( REF idB67D64896F6943cc98608CF4BB934A7D )
term.note: A unique implementation is typically associated with an implementation name, a version, and release number.

term.name: ITS-S application installation
term.definition: ITS-S application process installation ( REF idA70703E708334662A8EDA8C71037BAE7 ) within the application entity ( REF idB67D64896F6943cc98608CF4BB934A7D )

term.name: ITS-S application process
term.definition: element in an ITS station ( REF idF1E402D380EE478c957A2FF53D9EA0C5 ) that performs information processing for an ITS-S service ( REF idED2A90BFB7F249ffBB47A5827835D6E0 )

term.name: ITS-S application process installation
term.definition: installation of an implementation of an ITS-S application process ( REF id371D609484264a3598C7092967DD21DD ) on an ITS station ( REF idF1E402D380EE478c957A2FF53D9EA0C5 )
term.note: An implementation is typically associated with an implementation name, a version, and a release number.
An installation is typically associated with a specific license code or serial number.

figure.name: Hardstanding
Road reservation component graphic
Road reservation component terms

term.name: carriageway
term.definition: contiguous area of roadway ( REF id3F880EDEBFE84014A43B46167936F4B1 ) along a road segment ( REF idC615C2E3B7124c83B83FE649EAF6AD04 )
term.note: A carriageway is comprised of one or more traffic lanes (i.e., the travelled way) and could include shoulders and lay-bys.
Carriageways are separated by physical traffic separators.
When looking at a cross-section of the road reservation, the driving space consists of all of the carriageways.

term.name: cross-section
term.definition: transverse view of road geometry
term.note: The transverse view provides a vertical section of the ground and carriageway at right angles to the centre line of the carriageway.
term.example: Figure A-23

term.name: driving space
term.definition: area above the roadway ( REF id3F880EDEBFE84014A43B46167936F4B1 ) that is primarily intended for the movement of vehicles ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A )
term.note: In practice, the driving space design considers a variety of issues, which might result in suboptimal road segments that violate normal design guidelines. Such locations are typically posted with warning signs, but they are still "designed for the movement of vehicles."
While the driving space is designed with certain vehicle characteristics in mind, local regulations typically allow a wider set of vehicles to use the driving space.

term.name: dual carriageway road segment
term.definition: roadway ( REF id3F880EDEBFE84014A43B46167936F4B1 ) comprised of exactly two carriageways ( REF id855CC715739D462e9790E893914D8768 )
term.note: The PIARC term is "dual carriageway road" and is recognized as a preferred term. Per the definitions provided in this document, "dual carriageway road segment" is more accurate and is the most preferred term. The term "dual carriageway" by itself is not preferred but admitted.
The term "divided highway" is the equivalent American English term.
The two carriageways are typically designed for travel in opposite directions.

term.name: hard shoulder
term.definition: part of the paved carriageway ( REF id855CC715739D462e9790E893914D8768 ) designed to support traffic loads but not normally intended for driving
term.note: A hard shoulder can be narrow or wide enough for a traffic lane.
A hard shoulder can have a surface that discourages usage as a driving surface in some countries.

term.name: hardstanding
term.definition: part of a paved carriageway that is not a traffic lane, hard shoulder, or lay-by.
term.note: Hardstanding can include edges of a hard shoulder outside of designated lane markings, slips for future connector roads, etc.
term.example: See Figure A-23

term.name: lane
term.definition: <generic> portion of the road reservation ( REF idF9F0ACCE2D49434a803C0D87211F753A ) designed to accommodate a single line of moving material entities ( REF idC941C5B14FFB4aecAA18427AF3D1435A ) along its length
term.note: Lanes are often bounded by lane markings.
Lanes may be significantly wider than the normal vehicle width to allow variance in lane position of the vehicle as well as for various vehicle dimensions.
The "lane" nomenclature typically refers to motor vehicle usage, but can also refer to other purposes, such as sidewalks.
term.example: traffic lane, cycle lane, sidewalk

term.name: lay-by
term.definition: short length of paved carriageway ( REF id855CC715739D462e9790E893914D8768 ) at its edge designed to allow a vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) to draw out of the travel lanes and stop temporarily
term.note: Lay-bys are not part of a hard shoulder.
Lay-bys might be used for emergency situations, picking up/dropping off passengers, etc.

term.name: multiple carriageway road segment
term.definition: roadway ( REF id3F880EDEBFE84014A43B46167936F4B1 ) comprised of more than two carriageways ( REF id855CC715739D462e9790E893914D8768 )
term.note: The PIARC term is "multiple carriageway road" and is recognized as a preferred term. Per the definitions provided in this document, "dual carriageway road segment" is more accurate and is the most preferred term. The term "dual carriageway" by itself is not preferred but admitted.

The separate carriageways are typically designed for separate traffic for (often multiple) specific operational reasons, such as direction of travel, category of vehicle (e.g., high occupancy vehicle), local versus through travel, etc.

term.name: reserved lane
term.definition: traffic lane ( REF id1240152ED5B6429eA0A4B380F1D798E4 ) restricted to a specific subset of road vehicles ( REF idCD96217608B748ad8F85A3F4059FD426 ) or user categories
term.note: A traffic lane may be reserved permanently or under certain conditions or times.
term.example: Bus lane
High-occupancy vehicle lane

term.name: road reservation
term.definition: area legally reserved for road transport purposes and support
term.note: Support includes physical equipment such as safety devices, signage, and controller cabinets as well as access by maintenance vehicles and personnel.
The road reservation includes all carriageways as well as width to allow for roadside devices, shoulders, verges, footways, drainage facilities, sound walls, slopes, embankments, etc.

term.name: roadside
term.definition: portion of the road reservation ( REF idF9F0ACCE2D49434a803C0D87211F753A ) excluding all roadways ( REF id3F880EDEBFE84014A43B46167936F4B1 ) and driving spaces ( REF id3F880EDEBFE84014A43B46167936F4B1 )
term.note: Roadside, shoulder, and verge define similar but slightly different concepts.

term.name: roadway
term.definition: part of the surface of the road reservation ( REF idF9F0ACCE2D49434a803C0D87211F753A ) primarily designed for the movement of vehicles ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) that comply with a specified set of requirements
term.note: A roadway is characterized using a cross-section of a road facility as the roadway characteristics often change along the length of the road. See "road", "road section", "road segment", and "road link" for different types of stretches of roadway.

In practice, the roadway design considers a variety of issues, which might result in suboptimal road segments that violate normal design guidelines. Such locations are typically posted with warning signs, but they are still "designed for the movement of vehicles."
The roadway includes any contiguous hard shoulders, hardstanding, and reserved lanes.
While the roadway is designed with certain vehicle characteristics in mind, local regulations typically allow a wider set of vehicles to use the roadway.

term.name: shoulder
term.definition: either a hard shoulder ( REF idE4E923A99DE642ddA086B6556B1D8CA7 ) or a soft shoulder ( REF id96C94C547EA7427dB675A3BD87BF1D35 )
term.note: In some jurisdictions, a shoulder can be used for emergency stops and/or other purposes in addition to providing a clear zone for safety purposes.
Roadside, shoulder, and verge define similar but slightly different concepts.

term.name: single carriageway road segment
term.definition: roadway ( REF id3F880EDEBFE84014A43B46167936F4B1 ) comprised of exactly one carriageway ( REF id855CC715739D462e9790E893914D8768 )
term.note: The PIARC term is "single carriageway road" and is recognized as a preferred term. Per the definitions provided in this document, "single carriageway road segment" is more accurate and is the most preferred term. The term "single carriageway" by itself is not preferred but admitted.
A single carriageway road segment could have multiple lanes and could allow travel in opposite directions
The term "undivided highway" is the equivalent American English term.

term.name: soft shoulder
term.definition: unpaved part of the road reservation ( REF idF9F0ACCE2D49434a803C0D87211F753A ) not belonging to the carriageway ( REF id855CC715739D462e9790E893914D8768 ) but providing lateral support to it
term.note: Soft shoulders are not normally intended for driving.
Soft shoulders often have a grass or gravel surface.

term.name: traffic lane
term.definition: portion of carriageway ( REF id855CC715739D462e9790E893914D8768 ) designed to accommodate a single line of moving road vehicles ( REF idCD96217608B748ad8F85A3F4059FD426 )
term.note: A traffic lane might be bi-directional, such as a single lane road, a two-way turn/overtaking lane, or a reversible flow lane.
Some jurisdictions allow supplemental uses of a traffic lane, such as multiple motorcycles sharing the width of a traffic lane or allowing a bicycle to use the edge of a lane.
The term "lane" is often used to refer to "traffic lane" when the context is known to be traffic.

term.name: travelled way
term.definition: part of the roadway that is currently intended for transport purposes
term.note: The travelled way does not include hard shoulders, hardstanding, or other areas that are not currently intended for normal operational use. In other words, while these other areas are "designed" for transport purposes, they are not "intended" for normal transport purposes (at present); rather these extra areas exist for safety and other exceptional use conditions.

While the limits of the roadway are defined by the design of the physical infrastructure and are generally static; the limits of the travelled way can be dynamic, such as in the case of a hard shoulder for emergency use being converted into hard shoulder running operation.

term.name: usable width
term.definition: all traffic lanes ( REF id1240152ED5B6429eA0A4B380F1D798E4 ) of a carriageway ( REF id855CC715739D462e9790E893914D8768 )

term.name: verge
term.definition: unpaved part of the roadside ( REF id718D31DE1698436a9BA71D3F4512432A ) designed for travel safety purposes
term.note: A verge can separate two lanes of different modes, separate a traffic lane from a ditch, or separate a lane from another safety hazard.
Roadside, shouldder, and verge define similar but slightly different concepts.

figure.name: Physical traffic separator terms

term.name: central reservation
term.definition: part of the road reservation ( REF idF9F0ACCE2D49434a803C0D87211F753A ) between carriageways ( REF id855CC715739D462e9790E893914D8768 ) designed for travel safety purposes
term.note: A central reservation can be paved or unpaved and can be equipped with a safety barrier, rails, or other devices.

term.name: Jersey barrier
term.definition: physical traffic separator ( REF id947856123B8C483fA4EA168B5D71D241 ) that consists of a wall with a wide, sloped base designed to divert vehicles back into their traffic lane ( REF id1240152ED5B6429eA0A4B380F1D798E4 )
term.note: Jersey barriers are typically modular. They are typically made of concrete but can also be made with other materials such as plastic filled with water or sand.

term.name: physical traffic separator
term.definition: mechanism used to physically separate carriageways ( REF id855CC715739D462e9790E893914D8768 )
term.note: Mechanisms include various types of barriers, such as walls, rails, pylons, kerbs, and ditches, as well as open, unpaved space. If two streams of traffic are only separated by paved space (including any markings and rumble strips), they share a common carriageway.

figure.name: Alternate mode graphic
Alternate mode infrastructure component terms

term.name: cycle lane
term.definition: lane ( REF idDAF8D75AA574422cADE5F6D094406BB4 ) designed for the through movement of cycles
term.note: Cycle lanes are typically much narrower than traffic lanes.
Cycle lanes are typically part of either a carriageway or a cycleway.
Cycle lanes could also allow and be designed for motorized vehicles (e.g., e-scooters, mopeds, etc.) with similar performance characteristics as human-powered cycles, subject to local regulations.

term.name: cycleway
term.definition: infrastructure primarily designed for the use of cycles and separate from a carriageway ( REF id855CC715739D462e9790E893914D8768 )
term.note: Local legislation might allow cycleways to be used by a variety of low-speed vehicles (e.g., low-speed scooters, skateboards, etc.) and might share usage of other low-speed modes such as pedestrians, horseback riders, etc.

term.name: footway
term.definition: lane ( REF idDAF8D75AA574422cADE5F6D094406BB4 ) primarily designed for the movement of pedestrians
term.note: A paved footway is called a "pavement" in the British English.
Regulations typically allow footways to be used by other ultra-low speed users, such as the users of wheelchairs and strollers.

term.name: sidewalk
term.definition: footway ( REF id5B3BE81CF43C4c4bA8E9EEF5E12EDA6C ) along a roadside ( REF id718D31DE1698436a9BA71D3F4512432A )

figure.name: Infrastructure operating mode terms

term.name: hard shoulder for emergency use
term.definition: operating mode of a hard shoulder that allows operation of emergency, construction, maintenance, or other special use vehicles or for emergency stopping and is prohibited for other vehicle usage

term.name: hard shoulder running
term.definition: operating mode of a hard shoulder that allows operation of general-purpose vehicles as an extra lane

figure.name: Road network terms

term.name: lane link
term.definition: link ( REF id72937CE094414775B90C995DFCB64EEB ) that represents a lane of a road link ( REF idE86C320F77B445a18BB03478ACD8CBB2 )
term.note: A lane segment might start or end at locations other than the start or end of the corresponding road segment (e.g., a lane may start mid-block).
A lane segment only includes the sequential lane links, it does not include lane links from adjacent lanes.

term.name: lane segment
term.definition: link ( REF id72937CE094414775B90C995DFCB64EEB ) that represents a contiguous length of a lane link ( REF idE28C5D7863C84be78BBC6FDBB1153BBB ) characterized by the same physical characteristics

term.name: link
term.definition: <road network> component of a road model ( REF idB8E5C5BA451347a0A348DC3F11BA7DA5 ) that represents a connection between two nodes ( REF id32DA2E8F5F69415a9D62BD51CF4FAC92 )
term.note: A link might be curvilinear and might have various attributes such as width.

term.name: node
term.definition: <road network> component of a road model ( REF idB8E5C5BA451347a0A348DC3F11BA7DA5 ) representing a point location of the road network graph
term.note: The point location typically represents a point along the road which might be used to designate the location of a junction, public transport stop, jurisdictional boundary, termination point, etc.

term.name: road
term.definition: curvilinear length of roadway ( REF id3F880EDEBFE84014A43B46167936F4B1 ) that shares the same identification
term.note: A length of the road network may be referenced by multiple designators (e.g., Main Street and Route 7). In this case, there would be two "roads" that share the same set of "carriageways".
A road can change directions at a junction.
The identification is generally a name or number.

term.name: road link
term.definition: link ( REF id72937CE094414775B90C995DFCB64EEB ) representing a contiguous length of a road ( REF id72937CE094414775B90C995DFCB64EEB ) between two nodes ( REF id32DA2E8F5F69415a9D62BD51CF4FAC92 ) of operational or managerial significance
term.note: The operational characteristics of the nodes would relate to the type of road model. For example, a traffic system might base its road links on nodes that represent junctions and road terminators.

term.name: road model
term.definition: representation of a road network ( REF idEF0DB12C0BE247319EF2AC75AC234F8F )
term.note: Road models for different systems will often define different models. For example, a public transport system might define road links based on the location of bus stops while a traffic system might define road links based on the location of junctions.

term.name: road network
term.definition: interconnected collection of roads ( REF id72937CE094414775B90C995DFCB64EEB )

term.name: road section
term.definition: aggregation of one or more road links ( REF idE86C320F77B445a18BB03478ACD8CBB2 ) that represents a contiguous length of a road ( REF id72937CE094414775B90C995DFCB64EEB ) that shares the same management and operational strategies
term.note: Different road models might divide the same road into different road sections.
term.example: A traffic signal timing plan is applied to one road section.

term.name: road segment
term.definition: link ( REF id72937CE094414775B90C995DFCB64EEB ) that represents a contiguous length of a road link ( REF idE86C320F77B445a18BB03478ACD8CBB2 ) characterized by the same physical characteristics
term.note: The definition of road segments is highly dependent on what characteristics are modelled by the implementation. Characteristics that might result in a new road segment include addition or subtraction of a lane, a change in roadway width, the change of road type (e.g., start/end of a bridge), etc.

figure.name: Junction terms

term.name: egress lane
term.definition: traffic lane ( REF id1240152ED5B6429eA0A4B380F1D798E4 ) designed for exiting a junction ( REF id6C52075FBEAD42d4B0FB9C8A7F8FD833 )

term.name: egress link
term.definition: all egress lanes ( REF idCC2F0AF206E94b6c811F65B1BC7B60A7 ) on a road link ( REF idC615C2E3B7124c83B83FE649EAF6AD04 )

term.name: grade separated manoeuvre
term.definition: manoeuvre ( REF id04E1EDE4CEA745d89693A1CAED746C7C ) that is vertically separated from one or more manoeuvres that cross its two-dimensional path

term.name: ingress lane
term.definition: traffic lane ( REF id1240152ED5B6429eA0A4B380F1D798E4 ) designed for entering a junction ( REF id6C52075FBEAD42d4B0FB9C8A7F8FD833 )

term.name: ingress link
term.definition: all ingress lanes ( REF idA779A8E79A9446949679D6C81EA7934A ) on a road link ( REF idC615C2E3B7124c83B83FE649EAF6AD04 )

term.name: interchange
term.definition: junction ( REF id6C52075FBEAD42d4B0FB9C8A7F8FD833 ) with at least one grade separated manoeuvre ( REF idCEAE137FA7454a6c955DD7B7F50538E2 )
term.note: The grade separation allows travellers on the link to pass unimpeded through the interchange when congestion is not present.
The term "interchange" typically refers to the facilities that enable all available manoeuvres at the grade-separated intersection, which typically includes multiple junctions.

term.name: intersection
term.definition: space where two or more roads ( REF id72937CE094414775B90C995DFCB64EEB ) meet or cross
term.note: Intersections can be associated with zero junctions, such as a motorway crossing a road without any connecting ramps, or can be associated with multiple junctions, such as a diamond interchange.

Complex intersections can be viewed as multiple intersections by providing separate designations for distinct road links. For example, one model could depict a complex intersection as being associated with multiple junctions; another model could depict the same physical infrastructure as being multiple intersections that are interconnected by different roads, each with its own designator (e.g., "ramp from northbound Road A to eastbound Road B").

term.name: intersection manoeuvre
term.definition: <junction> movement from an ingress lane ( REF idA779A8E79A9446949679D6C81EA7934A ) to an egress lane ( REF idCC2F0AF206E94b6c811F65B1BC7B60A7 )
term.note: The term "maneuver" is the American English spelling.

term.name: junction
term.definition: intersection ( REF idA3C484DBF15D4b338F5C8C0A15EA4F2E ) that allows travellers to change roads ( REF id72937CE094414775B90C995DFCB64EEB )

term.name: junction at-grade
term.definition: junction ( REF id6C52075FBEAD42d4B0FB9C8A7F8FD833 ) without any grade separated manoeuvres ( REF idCEAE137FA7454a6c955DD7B7F50538E2 )

figure.name: Location type terms

term.name: area location
term.definition: spatial location ( REF id3A8D97796CC142fa8882F36C623AA755 ) enclosed within two-dimensional boundary/boundaries across a defined surface
term.note: The boundary may consist of a single (e.g., a circle) or multiple (e.g., the boundaries of city limits) curvilinear lines and might consist of multiple enclosed areas.
term.example: British Isles

term.name: geographic point location
term.definition: well defined geographic place described by one coordinate tuple
term.note: The "geolocation" term is a short version of the term used within some ITS communities.

term.name: linear location
term.definition: spatial location ( REF id3A8D97796CC142fa8882F36C623AA755 ) that extends between two point locations ( REF id877B14CA611F495089D65BE3C5CC9A53 ) along a defined path
term.note: The path might exhibit 3-dimensional characteristics.

term.name: location
term.definition: particular place or position
term.note: The term "location" by itself is a broad term that can be used to reference spatial, computer memory, imaginary, and other locations.

term.name: point location
term.definition: spatial location ( REF id3A8D97796CC142fa8882F36C623AA755 ) with no length in any of the spatial dimensions

term.name: spatial location
term.definition: location ( REF idDA3B34E1052A42fd993CBD5F6ED740E6 ) within three-dimensional space
term.note: The "location" could be a point (consuming no space) or could consume space in one, two, or three dimensions. In any case, the location is identified within a larger space.
Within ITS, locations are typically locations on or near the surface of the earth.

figure.name: Location referencing terms

term.name: dynamic spatial reference
term.definition: spatial reference ( REF id0F23B7B6B1C64d828035A246CDCC780C ) generated on-the-fly based on geographic properties in a digital map database

term.name: gazetteer
term.definition: register of spatial references ( REF id0F23B7B6B1C64d828035A246CDCC780C ) of one or more location sub-types containing some information regarding position
term.note: The positional information need not be coordinates but could be descriptive.
term.source: ISO 19112:2019, 3.1.1, modified to fit our concept model

term.name: geographic identifier
term.definition: spatial reference ( REF id0F23B7B6B1C64d828035A246CDCC780C ) in the form of a label or code
term.note: The term "location code" has been used previously in ISO/TC 204 standards, but "geographic identifier" is preferred to be more consistent with ISO/TC 211 work.
term.example: "Spain" is an example of a label (country name); "SW1P 3AD" is an example of a code (postcode).
term.source: ISO 19112:2019, 3.1.2, note and deprecated term added

term.name: link location
term.definition: pre-coded spatial reference ( REF id3A329C6B79D9436bA72E60C0685FE27D ) defined within the road network ( REF idEF0DB12C0BE247319EF2AC75AC234F8F ) database

term.name: location referencing
term.definition: process used to develop a spatial reference ( REF id0F23B7B6B1C64d828035A246CDCC780C )

term.name: pre-coded spatial reference
term.definition: spatial reference ( REF id0F23B7B6B1C64d828035A246CDCC780C ) using a unique identifier that is agreed upon in both sender and receiver system to select a location ( REF id3A8D97796CC142fa8882F36C623AA755 ) from a set of pre-coded locations

term.name: spatial reference
term.definition: description of a spatial location ( REF id3A8D97796CC142fa8882F36C623AA755 ) in the real world according to a defined reference system
term.note: The rules need not be formal coordinates but could be descriptive.
The term "location reference" has been used within ITS, but the term "spatial reference" is preferred to better align with activities of ISO/TC 211.
term.example: Coordinate tuple: 51.476852, -0.000500

figure.name: Generic service terms

term.name: service
term.definition: provision of one or more capabilities, functionalities, or facilities to enable one or more tasks to fulfil a need ( REF id8C060C793CE14fb88B50E52BD3A3FDE6 )

term.name: service provider
term.definition: entity ( REF id040D6A1B412A4cc6921882357A58F747 ) that delivers one or more services ( REF id1C826F4DC7744eb7B8DDB33EF68A28F5 )

term.name: user
term.definition: entity ( REF id040D6A1B412A4cc6921882357A58F747 ) that has a need ( REF id8C060C793CE14fb88B50E52BD3A3FDE6 ) to be fulfilled
term.note: The term "consumer" can be used when fulfilling the need results in the consumption of a resource.

term.name: user need
term.definition: factor or condition necessary to achieve desired results within a specified context of use

figure.name: Transport service terms

term.name: transport need
term.definition: <transport> need ( REF id8C060C793CE14fb88B50E52BD3A3FDE6 ) to transport one or more transport items to a different location

term.name: transport provider
term.definition: <transport> entity ( REF id040D6A1B412A4cc6921882357A58F747 ) that delivers one or more transport services ( REF id5F69F95814304a3991719C6E60838C0A )

term.name: transport service
term.definition: <transport> service ( REF id1C826F4DC7744eb7B8DDB33EF68A28F5 ) that delivers one or more material entities ( REF idC941C5B14FFB4aecAA18427AF3D1435A ) from one location to another to satisfy a transport need ( REF id3B0C62628A72424e98B2D5C2F2BBCD36 )
term.note: The material entities delivered might be people and/or goods.

term.name: transport user
term.definition: <transport> consumer ( REF id8B698530E3B946b3B78C2E6C58FE87D7 ) that has a transport need ( REF id3B0C62628A72424e98B2D5C2F2BBCD36 ) to be fulfilled

figure.name: ITS service terms

term.name: ITS service
term.definition: functionality that fulfils one or more ITS user needs ( REF idC312FB0B6C1140db86F158458C5AC4B8 )

term.name: ITS service provider
term.definition: entity ( REF id040D6A1B412A4cc6921882357A58F747 ) that delivers one or more ITS services ( REF id4D485872E9EE414e9CE1AB855A03540B )
term.note: Cooperative ITS services often require multiple entities cooperatively working together to provide a unified service where the individual entities are simultaneously ITS service providers and ITS users.

term.name: ITS user
term.definition: entity ( REF id040D6A1B412A4cc6921882357A58F747 ) that has an ITS user need ( REF idC312FB0B6C1140db86F158458C5AC4B8 ) to be fulfilled

term.name: ITS user need
term.definition: need ( REF id8C060C793CE14fb88B50E52BD3A3FDE6 ) of an entity external to the intelligent transport system for a surface transport system ( REF id261629D58D7B439b8DAE5905D2EEF4D5 ) benefit that can be met with the use of information, communication, sensor, and/or control technologies
term.example: Increasing safety, sustainability, efficiency, and/or comfort

figure.name: ITS-S service terms

term.name: ITS-S service
term.definition: <ITS-S> performance of one or more tasks to fulfil an ITS-S user need ( REF idAE2F5ED40F9549e2A07B4C547A3C4CF4 ) for an ITS-S user ( REF idFFC4D737010249d0B062A188246E1DAD )

term.name: ITS-S service provider
term.definition: <ITS-S> ITS-S ( REF idF1E402D380EE478c957A2FF53D9EA0C5 ) that delivers one or more ITS-S services ( REF idED2A90BFB7F249ffBB47A5827835D6E0 )

term.name: ITS-S user
term.definition: <ITS-S> entity ( REF id040D6A1B412A4cc6921882357A58F747 ) that has an ITS-S user need ( REF idAE2F5ED40F9549e2A07B4C547A3C4CF4 ) to be fulfilled

term.name: ITS-S user need
term.definition: <ITS-S> need ( REF id8C060C793CE14fb88B50E52BD3A3FDE6 ) for processing within a bounded, secure, managed domain ( REF id866BE3730A304564BBC18CA138D01808 )

figure.name: ITS-S communication service terms

term.name: ITS-S communication need
term.definition: <ITS-S> need ( REF id8C060C793CE14fb88B50E52BD3A3FDE6 ) for communication functionality that connects an ITS-S ( REF idF1E402D380EE478c957A2FF53D9EA0C5 ) to other nodes

term.name: ITS-S communication process
term.definition: <ITS-S> entity ( REF id040D6A1B412A4cc6921882357A58F747 ) that delivers one or more ITS-S communication services ( REF id04F387DD652043039464AA4FA280AB16 )

term.name: ITS-S communication service
term.definition: <ITS-S> performance of one or more tasks to fulfil an ITS-S communication need ( REF id202B9BA1EA2F4bfbA3D5BE04ACA3E2D5 ) for an ITS-S communication user ( REF id1FC1FE8C6F1A41a7AECE0F7A9C874620 )

term.name: ITS-S communication user
term.definition: <ITS-S> entity ( REF id040D6A1B412A4cc6921882357A58F747 ) that has an ITS-S communication need ( REF id202B9BA1EA2F4bfbA3D5BE04ACA3E2D5 ) to be fulfilled

figure.name: Transport-related sharing terms

term.name: public transport
term.definition: transport service ( REF id5F69F95814304a3991719C6E60838C0A ) that is publicly accessible enabling the movement of one or more persons ( REF idA195A5913A44427f96436DF49EAAC159 )
term.note: A public transport service can be scheduled or on-demand
A public transport service is based on the use of publicly accessible transport means for collective, shared, or individual use.
term.example: bus, tram, cable car, metro, train, and ferry are examples of public transport means for collective use
publicly accessible shared cars, shared bikes, and shared e-scooters are examples of public transport means for shared and individual use

term.name: shared transport service
term.definition: transport service ( REF id5F69F95814304a3991719C6E60838C0A ) that relies upon the same resources to fulfil the transport needs ( REF id3B0C62628A72424e98B2D5C2F2BBCD36 ) of multiple unrelated transport users ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) and where the transport provider ( REF idA3BC9C78F77A4be7BADD00079FED8167 ) has the primary responsibility for the operation of the transport mode
term.note: A shared transport system might not be dependent upon a vehicle and/or could be multi-modal. For example, a letter courier service could rely on walking and public transport.

Responsibilities of the transport service might be further delegated to others. For example, a courier service relying on public transport would delegate the operation of the transport mode to the public transport operator.

term.name: shared vehicle service
term.definition: transport service ( REF id5F69F95814304a3991719C6E60838C0A ) that sequentially provides the same vehicles ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) to multiple unrelated transport users ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) and where the transport user has the primary responsibility for the operation of the vehicle
term.note: As there should only be one operator of a vehicle at any time, a shared vehicle service should use a sequential operational model.
This term can be specialized by replacing "vehicle" with any defined vehicle type (e.g., "automated vehicle sharing").

term.name: transport sharing
term.definition: using a shared transport service ( REF idAF252202FB50473fB51E56F3FBE6932E )

term.name: vehicle sharing
term.definition: using a shared vehicle service ( REF id8C73DE6A6FCF4643AE8C1A25A4E4C9CF )
term.note: This term can be specialized by replacing "vehicle" with any defined vehicle type; however, in some cases the preferred form is to consolidate terms (e.g., "carsharing" rather than "passenger car sharing").

figure.name: Contractual model terms

term.name: contractual model
term.definition: legal framework for the agreement between a service provider ( REF id8B7ACC49A9CB45f18C3634024C5A6318 ) and a user ( REF id8B698530E3B946b3B78C2E6C58FE87D7 )
term.note: Contracts might be via a third party, implied or verbal, especially in the case of peer-to-peer.

term.name: corporate customer model
term.definition: contractual model ( REF idB3582A5C7E9B4749A708EE0EECBCAC51 ) where the user ( REF id8B698530E3B946b3B78C2E6C58FE87D7 ) is a commercial entity
term.example: A business purchasing monthly public transport passes for its employees
A commercial entity using a commercial courier service for package delivery

term.name: government customer model
term.definition: contractual model ( REF idB3582A5C7E9B4749A708EE0EECBCAC51 ) where the user ( REF id8B698530E3B946b3B78C2E6C58FE87D7 ) is a governmental entity
term.example: A governmental entity using a commercial courier service for package delivery

term.name: peer-to-peer model
term.definition: private customer model ( REF idB3A5B0B94EE3469a910FC48F00AD16B4 ) where the service provider ( REF id8B7ACC49A9CB45f18C3634024C5A6318 ) is an individual
term.note: The service provider and user can connect and/or contract through a third-party service.
term.example: ridesourcing

term.name: private customer model
term.definition: contractual model ( REF idB3582A5C7E9B4749A708EE0EECBCAC51 ) where the user ( REF id8B698530E3B946b3B78C2E6C58FE87D7 ) is an individual

figure.name: Financial model terms

term.name: commercial
term.definition: financial model ( REF id1C9A28E75C534b08939F72CA1207904D ) where services ( REF id1C826F4DC7744eb7B8DDB33EF68A28F5 ) are provided with a profit motive

term.name: cooperative
term.definition: financial model ( REF id1C9A28E75C534b08939F72CA1207904D ) where users ( REF id8B698530E3B946b3B78C2E6C58FE87D7 ) partner to defray the costs of a service ( REF id1C826F4DC7744eb7B8DDB33EF68A28F5 )
term.note: Cooperative models are exclusive commercial and public models.

term.name: financial model
term.definition: economic framework for the agreement between a service provider ( REF id8B7ACC49A9CB45f18C3634024C5A6318 ) and a user ( REF id8B698530E3B946b3B78C2E6C58FE87D7 )

term.name: fractional ownership
term.definition: cooperative ( REF idBF1211A2A721402c8450C76DD85215BD ) financial model where users ( REF id8B698530E3B946b3B78C2E6C58FE87D7 ) partner to support the purchase, maintenance, and overhead costs associated with a service ( REF id1C826F4DC7744eb7B8DDB33EF68A28F5 )

term.name: membership-based
term.definition: characteristic of a financial model ( REF id1C9A28E75C534b08939F72CA1207904D ) that requires users ( REF id8B698530E3B946b3B78C2E6C58FE87D7 ) to enter into an agreement prior to receiving services ( REF id1C826F4DC7744eb7B8DDB33EF68A28F5 )
term.note: The agreement might be associated with fees.
The agreement might be minimal, such as collecting user information for business purposes.
The membership may be granted as a part of a broader agreement. For example, a university bus system might restrict access to students and faculty.

term.name: mutual benefit
term.definition: cooperative ( REF idBF1211A2A721402c8450C76DD85215BD ) financial model where users ( REF id8B698530E3B946b3B78C2E6C58FE87D7 ) partner on a per-use basis

term.name: open-access
term.definition: characteristic of a financial model ( REF id1C9A28E75C534b08939F72CA1207904D ) that does not require membership within an organization to receive services ( REF id1C826F4DC7744eb7B8DDB33EF68A28F5 )
term.note: This includes models where membership is optional and might provide extra benefits.

term.name: private
term.definition: financial model ( REF id1C9A28E75C534b08939F72CA1207904D ) where services ( REF id1C826F4DC7744eb7B8DDB33EF68A28F5 ) are provided to members of the owning organization without usage fees
term.example: Fleet vehicles of an employer

term.name: public
term.definition: financial model ( REF id1C9A28E75C534b08939F72CA1207904D ) where services ( REF id1C826F4DC7744eb7B8DDB33EF68A28F5 ) are provided by an administrative authority in an attempt to better serve societal interests
term.note: The transport service is typically offered to the transport consumer for less than the full capital and operating cost of providing the service, but this is not a requirement.

Typically, the administrative authority is a local government agency; but it could be another administrative authority, such as the national government or a commercial entity managing transport needs on their campus.

figure.name: Operational model terms

term.name: concurrent
term.definition: operational model ( REF id9EE684356599469b905CF09986D497E9 ) where services ( REF id1C826F4DC7744eb7B8DDB33EF68A28F5 ) might be provided to multiple users ( REF id8B698530E3B946b3B78C2E6C58FE87D7 ) at any one time

term.name: dynamic route
term.definition: <transport service> concurrent ( REF idE5D76E7905404edfBA6A94FCEC721A6A ) operation where transported items can only be received or delivered at stopping points within a pre-defined service corridor
term.note: The service corridor is defined by the provider, who may impose further restrictions on where stops are allowed.
The service corridor often includes a communal point of interest (e.g., an airport, transit hub, etc) as a fixed stopping point.
term.example: Airport shuttle

term.name: fixed route
term.definition: <transport service> concurrent ( REF idE5D76E7905404edfBA6A94FCEC721A6A ) operation where transported items can only be received or delivered at stopping points contained in a pre-defined sequence
term.example: Traditional fixed-route bus line

term.name: operational model
term.definition: logistical framework for the agreement between a service provider ( REF id8B7ACC49A9CB45f18C3634024C5A6318 ) and a user ( REF id8B698530E3B946b3B78C2E6C58FE87D7 )
term.note: The logistical framework might set restrictions on how a passenger and/or good is received, transported, and/or delivered.

term.name: paired on-demand
term.definition: <transport service> concurrent ( REF idE5D76E7905404edfBA6A94FCEC721A6A ) operation where the transport provider ( REF idA3BC9C78F77A4be7BADD00079FED8167 ) may choose to divert from its path to service a new request from another transport user ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) while servicing an earlier transport consumer
term.example: ridesplitting

term.name: sequential
term.definition: operational model ( REF id9EE684356599469b905CF09986D497E9 ) where services ( REF id1C826F4DC7744eb7B8DDB33EF68A28F5 ) are provided to a single user ( REF id8B698530E3B946b3B78C2E6C58FE87D7 ) at any one time
term.note: A single transport consumer might request the transport of multiple passengers.
term.example: traditional taxi service

figure.name: Network model terms

term.name: free-floating
term.definition: <transport service> network model ( REF id6CC6271D3BFF40d888883E5BC1C00632 ) where the transport service ( REF id5F69F95814304a3991719C6E60838C0A ) may be initiated and terminated at any location meeting basic criteria
term.note: The basic criteria typically include geographic limits and requirements related to legal and safe locations.

term.name: network model
term.definition: infrastructure framework for the agreement between a service provider ( REF id8B7ACC49A9CB45f18C3634024C5A6318 ) and a user ( REF id8B698530E3B946b3B78C2E6C58FE87D7 )

term.name: station-based one-way
term.definition: <transport service> operational mode ( REF id6CC6271D3BFF40d888883E5BC1C00632 ) where the transport service ( REF id5F69F95814304a3991719C6E60838C0A ) is initiated and terminated at two different facilities managed by the transport provider ( REF idA3BC9C78F77A4be7BADD00079FED8167 )

term.name: station-based roundtrip
term.definition: <transport service> operational mode ( REF id6CC6271D3BFF40d888883E5BC1C00632 ) where the transport service ( REF id5F69F95814304a3991719C6E60838C0A ) is initiated and terminated at the same facility managed by the transport provider ( REF idA3BC9C78F77A4be7BADD00079FED8167 )

figure.name: Shared transport service terms

term.name: courier network service
term.definition: commercial ( REF id3AF823A8DE44425984FED140D4668259 ), peer-to-peer ( REF idABEF77BE95BA45a68CF387E17E03ED81 ) shared transport service ( REF idAF252202FB50473fB51E56F3FBE6932E ) that transports goods
term.note: The goods are typically small packages, letters, food, etc.

term.name: rideshare service
