term.definition: cooperative ( REF idBF1211A2A721402c8450C76DD85215BD ) shared transport service ( REF idAF252202FB50473fB51E56F3FBE6932E ) that transports passengers concurrently ( REF idE5D76E7905404edfBA6A94FCEC721A6A )

term.name: ridesourced service
term.definition: commercial ( REF id3AF823A8DE44425984FED140D4668259 ), peer-to-peer ( REF idABEF77BE95BA45a68CF387E17E03ED81 ) shared transport service ( REF idAF252202FB50473fB51E56F3FBE6932E ) that transports passengers

term.name: ridesplit service
term.definition: ridesourced service ( REF idF6E55203606D4d13BCD69D3349D0AE3B ) that serves passengers concurrently ( REF idE5D76E7905404edfBA6A94FCEC721A6A )

term.name: shuttle service
term.definition: shared transport service ( REF idAF252202FB50473fB51E56F3FBE6932E ) that transports passengers between two specified locations ( REF id3A8D97796CC142fa8882F36C623AA755 )
term.note: Each location might be defined as point, linear, or area locations; however, the areas of the two locations should not overlap.

term.name: taxi service
term.definition: commercial ( REF id3AF823A8DE44425984FED140D4668259 ) shared transport service ( REF idAF252202FB50473fB51E56F3FBE6932E ) that transports passengers sequentially ( REF idED3C7DDD53C34d7a87F9BF037CB98B16 )

term.name: taxi-share service
term.definition: commercial ( REF id3AF823A8DE44425984FED140D4668259 ) shared transport service ( REF idAF252202FB50473fB51E56F3FBE6932E ) that transports passengers concurrently ( REF idE5D76E7905404edfBA6A94FCEC721A6A )

figure.name: Shared vehicle terms

term.name: bikesharing service
term.definition: shared vehicle service ( REF id8C73DE6A6FCF4643AE8C1A25A4E4C9CF ) that shares bicycles
term.note: The term "bicycle sharing service" is admitted, but "bikesharing service" is preferred as it has fewer syllables.

term.name: carsharing service
term.definition: shared vehicle service ( REF id8C73DE6A6FCF4643AE8C1A25A4E4C9CF ) that shares passenger cars
term.note: The term "passenger car sharing service" is admitted but means the same thing.

figure.name: Transport service application terms

term.name: B2C mobility sharing app
term.definition: mobility app ( REF id1C90ED2B61D74f899D6D199CB9A2B785 ) that assists a transport user ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) in acquiring a transport service ( REF id5F69F95814304a3991719C6E60838C0A ) from a specific business

term.name: mobility app
term.definition: ITS-S application implementation ( REF id0FC1FF4E8B694277B63F2A0C167A0C87 ) designed to assist an individual transport consumer in understanding transport-related information, making decisions, and/or acting upon decisions

term.name: navigation app
term.definition: mobility app ( REF id1C90ED2B61D74f899D6D199CB9A2B785 ) that assists a transport user ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) to determine the best route to a destination

term.name: P2P mobility sharing app
term.definition: mobility app ( REF id1C90ED2B61D74f899D6D199CB9A2B785 ) that assists a transport user ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) in acquiring a transport service ( REF id5F69F95814304a3991719C6E60838C0A ) from an individual that participates in the mobility app's network

term.name: public transport app
term.definition: mobility app ( REF id1C90ED2B61D74f899D6D199CB9A2B785 ) that assists a transport user ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) in using a public transport ( REF id8D4AD407A8594d13A4947E6EA66408A6 ) system
term.note: A public transport app might include features such as viewing maps, searching routes and schedules, real-time arrival information, ticketing, electronic boarding pass, etc.

term.name: real-time traveller information app
term.definition: mobility app ( REF id1C90ED2B61D74f899D6D199CB9A2B785 ) that provides information about current travel conditions to a transport user ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 )

term.name: ridesourcing app
term.definition: P2P mobility sharing app ( REF id04D43929B0A547e69C9315F341AFDC37 ) for acquiring a ridesourced service ( REF idF6E55203606D4d13BCD69D3349D0AE3B )

term.name: taxi hailing app
term.definition: mobility app ( REF id1C90ED2B61D74f899D6D199CB9A2B785 ) that assists a transport user ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) in electronically requesting a taxi

term.name: trip aggregator app
term.definition: mobility app ( REF id1C90ED2B61D74f899D6D199CB9A2B785 ) that assists a transport user ( REF idE444860D95E5458a9BA4CF4BCE3EAD71 ) in planning trips that may span multiple vehicle modes or transport providers
term.note: The assistance might include reservations, ticketing, and similar services.

figure.name: Traveller terms

term.name: pedestrian
term.definition: person ( REF idA195A5913A44427f96436DF49EAAC159 ) who is travelling on foot

term.name: road user
term.definition: mobile material entity ( REF idC941C5B14FFB4aecAA18427AF3D1435A ) within the road reservation ( REF idF9F0ACCE2D49434a803C0D87211F753A )
term.example: pedestrians, road work personnel, vehicle occupants, occupied and unoccupied vehicles, horses, etc.

term.name: traveller
term.definition: person ( REF idA195A5913A44427f96436DF49EAAC159 ), in the role of a transport item ( REF idA4530852939B41f89A9140C5CBE4D1A3 ), who is headed to a destination

figure.name: Vehicle occupant terms

term.name: driver
term.definition: person ( REF idA195A5913A44427f96436DF49EAAC159 ) that is currently responsible for the dynamic driving task ( REF id53381BA7AB7F48d6AED7DBCA2D07E6C9 ) for the vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A )
term.note: The driver is typically onboard the vehicle but could be remote from the vehicle or automated logic.

term.name: in-vehicle driver
term.definition: driver ( REF id99035FCBCBED4af49063EB3F85FD7031 ) that performs the dynamic driving task ( REF id53381BA7AB7F48d6AED7DBCA2D07E6C9 ) using the vehicle's built-in input devices ( REF id9FA5E7B96F34461bAF17E2FB61512F95 ) to control the longitudinal and lateral movement of the vehicle

term.name: passenger
term.definition: person ( REF idA195A5913A44427f96436DF49EAAC159 ) who has a reservation to travel or is travelling in a vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) except for any crew, staff, or drivers

term.name: remote driver
term.definition: driver ( REF id99035FCBCBED4af49063EB3F85FD7031 ) that performs the dynamic driving task ( REF id53381BA7AB7F48d6AED7DBCA2D07E6C9 ) without using the vehicle's built-in input devices ( REF id9FA5E7B96F34461bAF17E2FB61512F95 ) to control the longitudinal and lateral movement of the vehicle
term.note: A remote driver may use a variety of physical input devices, but not any that are built into the vehicle.

term.name: vehicle occupant
term.definition: person ( REF idA195A5913A44427f96436DF49EAAC159 ) in or on a vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A )
term.note: A vehicle occupant in a stationary vehicle is not necessarily a traveller.

figure.name: Vehicle component terms

term.name: built-in vehicle input device
term.definition: input device ( REF idD912A6773D214e72BEC85F0D9A4529FA ) designed to be physically connected to a vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) and to remain connected even when the vehicle is not in use
term.note: Built-in input devices are typically considered to be a part of the vehicle.
Built-in input devices include devices that might be temporarily disconnected for security reasons (e.g., some radios are equipped with detachable front panels).
Built-in input devices require a maintenance operation to connect or disconnect.

term.name: input device
term.definition: <vehicle> material entity ( REF idC941C5B14FFB4aecAA18427AF3D1435A ) that can affect the vehicle's ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) operation
term.note: Input devices include those used to control the motion of the vehicle (e.g., a brake pedal), the state of vehicular equipment (e.g., headlight control), the configuration of the vehicle (e.g., temperature control), etc.
term.example: steering wheel, lever, pedal, knob, button, touch screen

term.name: motor
term.definition: material entity ( REF idC941C5B14FFB4aecAA18427AF3D1435A ) that converts energy into mechanical motion

term.name: nomadic vehicle input device
term.definition: input device ( REF idD912A6773D214e72BEC85F0D9A4529FA ) capable to be carried into, or in near proximity of, a vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) and connected as desired
term.note: Nomadic devices are often more closely associated with a person than they are with the vehicle.
Nomadic input devices do not require a maintenance operation to connect or disconnect.
term.example: A smartphone connected to a vehicle (via USB or Bluetooth) to provide driver navigation on the vehicle's large screen display

term.name: remote vehicle input device
term.definition: input device ( REF idD912A6773D214e72BEC85F0D9A4529FA ) designed to be electronically connected to a vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) even when the vehicle is not in close proximity

term.name: vehicle
term.definition: material entity ( REF idC941C5B14FFB4aecAA18427AF3D1435A ) designed to transport people or physical goods by changing its physical position

term.name: wheel
term.definition: circular material entity ( REF idC941C5B14FFB4aecAA18427AF3D1435A ) that rotates about an axle to facilitate movement of the vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A )

figure.name: Vehicle attribute terms

term.name: design speed
term.definition: <vehicle> maximum speed ( REF idCDB8A094578846dcB02F79FBE507F07D ) at which a vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) is intended to operate for a sustained period of time
term.note: The term "top speed" is defined in SAE J3194:2019 in relation to powered micromobility vehicles and is considered to be semantically equivalent to design speed.

term.name: speed
term.definition: rate of change of a material entities ( REF idC941C5B14FFB4aecAA18427AF3D1435A ) position with respect to a frame of reference
term.note: Speed is a function of time.
Speed is the scalar absolute value (magnitude) of velocity.

figure.name: Vehicle automation terms
figure.text: See SAE J3016 for more details.

term.name: ADS
term.definition: driving automation system ( REF id65AFD85E052043b0AB87514248666FFA ) that is able to perform the entire DDT ( REF id53381BA7AB7F48d6AED7DBCA2D07E6C9 ) on a sustained basis
term.note: The abbreviated form ("ADS") is the most preferred form and the alternate form ("Automated Driving System") uses initial capitals to avoid confusion with the more general "driving automation system".

term.name: ADS-dedicated vehicle
term.definition: ADS-equipped vehicle ( REF idA7CF87D985684eceB59879EF59C87184 ) designed for only driverless operation for complete trips

term.name: ADS-equipped vehicle
term.definition: vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) integrated with an ADS ( REF idE3B6FF9F65A448ffBA3B74876D599814 )
term.note: The terms "automated vehicle" and "AV" are often used in a colloquial form, however, these terms might be used to mean either an "ADS-equipped vehicle" or a "vehicle with an engaged ADS". The term "ADS-equipped vehicle" is preferred since it is more precise and descriptive in its meaning.

The term "autonomous vehicle" is also often used in a colloquial form and is even less well defined. The term is particularly problematic because the word "autonomous" has been used for a long time in the robotics and artificial intelligence research communities to signify systems that have the ability and authority to make decisions independently and self-sufficiently. Due to its imprecise and overly broad meaning, use of the term "autonomous vehicle" is discouraged.

This term can, and when possible should be, refined by identifying the level of automation. For example, the terms "level 5 ADS-equipped vehicle" and "level 5 automated vehicle" should be interpreted as "ADS-equipped vehicle where the ADS is a level 5 ADS."

This term only describes the capabilities of the vehicle, not its operational state. In other words, the term applies as long as the ADS is connected to the vehicle, whether the DDT is actively engaged or not.

term.name: conventional vehicle
term.definition: <driving automation> vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) designed to be operated by a person ( REF idA195A5913A44427f96436DF49EAAC159 ) during part or all of every trip.

term.name: DDT performance-relevant system failure
term.definition: malfunction in a vehicle system that prevents the driving automation system ( REF id65AFD85E052043b0AB87514248666FFA ) from reliably performing its portion of the DDT ( REF id53381BA7AB7F48d6AED7DBCA2D07E6C9 ) on a sustained basis
term.note: The malfunction may be internal to the driving automation system or part of another vehicle system.

term.name: driver spport system
term.definition: driving automation system ( REF id65AFD85E052043b0AB87514248666FFA ) that is only able to perform part of the DDT ( REF id53381BA7AB7F48d6AED7DBCA2D07E6C9 )
term.note: Driver support systems include Level 1 and Level 2 driving automation.

term.name: driving automation system
term.definition: hardware and software system ( REF id9F9DE40282B84b8aAD4F618C7836F09E ) that is able to perform part or all of the DDT ( REF id53381BA7AB7F48d6AED7DBCA2D07E6C9 ) on a sustained basis
term.note: In contrast to this generic term for any level 1-5 system, the specific term for a level 3-5 system is "Automated Driving System (ADS)." Given the similarity between the generic term, "driving automation system," and the level 3-5-specific term, "Automated Driving System," the latter term is intentionally capitalized when spelled out and reduced to its acronym, "ADS", as much as possible, while "driving automation system" should not be.
A driving automation system includes any system capable of level 1-5 driving automation.
Driving automation levels are defined in ISO/SAE 22736, which is also known as SAE J3016.
Driving automation levels include "level 1 driving automation", "level 2 driving automation", "level 3 ADS", "level 4 ADS", and "level 5 ADS".

term.name: dual-mode vehicle
term.definition: <driving automation> ADS-equipped vehicle ( REF idA7CF87D985684eceB59879EF59C87184 ) designed for both driverless operation and operation by a conventional driver ( REF id76D23D03F3624a68920FB5BE7FB40ED8 ) for complete trips

term.name: dynamic driving task
term.definition: all real-time operational and tactical functions required to operate a vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) in on-road traffic
term.note: The DDT includes lateral vehicle motion control, longitudinal vehicle motion control, monitoring the driving environment, object and event response execution, manoeuvre planning, and enhancing conspicuity.
The DDT excludes strategic functions such as trip scheduling and selection of destinations and waypoints.

term.name: fallback
term.definition: <driving automation> response by a person ( REF idA195A5913A44427f96436DF49EAAC159 ) to perform the DDT ( REF id53381BA7AB7F48d6AED7DBCA2D07E6C9 ) or by an ADS ( REF idE3B6FF9F65A448ffBA3B74876D599814 ) to achieve a minimal risk condition when the response is triggered upon violation of the defined operational design domain ( REF id4C8C89A0369D455c9FCE6187A7DD62FC ) constraints or in response to a DDT performance-relevant driving automation system failure ( REF idF18A70A730734210891943E1C5F988C3 )

term.name: fallback-ready user
term.definition: <driving automation> person ( REF idA195A5913A44427f96436DF49EAAC159 ) who is able to operate the vehicle if the Level 3 ADS ( REF id0D13CFB7427A423d9DBC082B91FCEE24 ) issues a request to intervene or if s/he otherwise identifies a condition that requires intervention to perform the DDT ( REF id53381BA7AB7F48d6AED7DBCA2D07E6C9 )

term.name: level 1 driving automation
term.definition: driver support system ( REF idB67B240E827E493eB1532275FAFAB9BE ) that provides either sustained lateral or sustained longitudinal vehicle motion control within a specific operational design domain ( REF id4C8C89A0369D455c9FCE6187A7DD62FC ) with the expectation that a conventional driver ( REF id76D23D03F3624a68920FB5BE7FB40ED8 ) completes the dynamic driving task
term.note: Other driving automation levels include "level 2 driving automation", "level 3 ADS", "level 4 ADS", and "level 5 ADS".

term.name: level 2 driving automation
term.definition: driver support system ( REF idB67B240E827E493eB1532275FAFAB9BE ) that provides sustained lateral and longitudinal vehicle motion control within a specific operational design domain ( REF id4C8C89A0369D455c9FCE6187A7DD62FC ) with the expectation that a conventional driver ( REF id76D23D03F3624a68920FB5BE7FB40ED8 ) completes the object and event detection and response
term.note: Other driving automation levels include "level 1 driving automation", "level 3 ADS", "level 4 ADS", and "level 5 ADS".

term.name: level 3 ADS
term.definition: ADS ( REF idE3B6FF9F65A448ffBA3B74876D599814 ) designed with the expectation that the fallback-ready user ( REF id4B4E9E64261E4f09B7F7579C8389B23F ) is available to intervene
term.note: Level 3 ADSs are restricted to operating within a specific ODD.
Other driving automation levels include "level 1 driving automation", "level 2 driving automation", "level 4 ADS", and "level 5 ADS".
The user might need to intervene due to an ADS-issued request, a DDT performance-relevant system failure, or other reasons.

term.name: level 4 ADS
term.definition: ADS ( REF idE3B6FF9F65A448ffBA3B74876D599814 ) that is capable of operating within a specific ODD ( REF id4C8C89A0369D455c9FCE6187A7DD62FC ) and providing its own fallback ( REF idDA84A3AE849442be8F2BEDE52CBDB60C ), without any expectation that a human driver ( REF id99035FCBCBED4af49063EB3F85FD7031 ) will respond to a request to intervene
term.note: Other driving automation levels include "level 1 driving automation", "level 2 driving automation", "level 3 ADS", and "level 5 ADS".

term.name: level 5 ADS
term.definition: ADS ( REF idE3B6FF9F65A448ffBA3B74876D599814 ) that is capable of unconditional (i.e., not ODD ( REF id4C8C89A0369D455c9FCE6187A7DD62FC )-specific) operation and providing its own fallback ( REF idDA84A3AE849442be8F2BEDE52CBDB60C ), without any expectation that a human driver ( REF id99035FCBCBED4af49063EB3F85FD7031 ) will respond to a request to intervene
term.note: Other driving automation levels include "level 1 driving automation", "level 2 driving automation", "level 3 ADS", and "level 4 ADS".

term.name: operational design domain
term.definition: set of operating conditions under which a given driving automation system ( REF id65AFD85E052043b0AB87514248666FFA ) or feature thereof is specifically designed to function
term.note: The conditions might include environmental, geographical, time-of-day, and/or other restrictions.
The conditions might require the presence or absence of certain traffic or roadway characteristics.
term.example: ADS feature designed to operate a vehicle only on fully access-controlled freeways in low-speed traffic, under fair weather conditions and optimal road maintenance conditions (e.g., good lane markings and not under construction).
ADS-dedicated vehicle designed to operate only within a geographically-defined area, and only during daylight at speeds not to exceed 25 mph.

figure.name: Vehicle connectivity terms

term.name: disconnected
term.definition: characteristic of a material entity ( REF idC941C5B14FFB4aecAA18427AF3D1435A ) that is or was equipped with communications equipment that is sufficiently physically disconnected such that the vehicle is no longer able to send data to or receive data from connected ( REF id49FF108A0CA140d49A439CF9BBABA1BB ) entities
term.note: The vehicle on-board equipment might still be present in the vehicle and might even be partially connected, but not in any operational sense.

term.name: off-grid
term.definition: characteristic of a material entity ( REF idC941C5B14FFB4aecAA18427AF3D1435A ) that is currently unable to send data to or receive data from connected ( REF id49FF108A0CA140d49A439CF9BBABA1BB ) entities

term.name: unconnected
term.definition: characteristic of a material entity ( REF idC941C5B14FFB4aecAA18427AF3D1435A ) that is equipped with communications equipment that is not active or is otherwise unable to send data to or receive data from connected ( REF id49FF108A0CA140d49A439CF9BBABA1BB ) entities

term.name: unequipped
term.definition: characteristic of a material entity ( REF idC941C5B14FFB4aecAA18427AF3D1435A ) that is not and has never been equipped with communications equipment for sending data to or receiving data from connected ( REF id49FF108A0CA140d49A439CF9BBABA1BB ) entities

figure.name: Vehicle speed terms

term.name: high vehicle speed
term.definition: speed of a vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) that exceeds free flow motorway speeds by a factor of two or more
term.note: Local regulations for the exact speed range vary.
term.example: A speed in excess of 198 km/h.

term.name: high-speed vehicle
term.definition: vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) with a design speed ( REF id94141E56EA294dfb8212E7FA5553D1F6 ) in the range of high vehicle speeds ( REF id70921DFB3F0949b6BC989C833A9DC907 )
term.example: high-speed train
racing car

term.name: low vehicle speed
term.definition: speed of a vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) that exceeds pedestrian speeds and is more typical of pedal cycles
term.note: Local regulations for the exact speed range vary.
term.example: SAE J3194:2019 associates this with a top speed in the range between 13 km/h and 32 km/h.

term.name: low-speed vehicle
term.definition: vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) with a design speed ( REF id94141E56EA294dfb8212E7FA5553D1F6 ) in the range of low vehicle speeds ( REF idA46C3767F5C14852A72F2B1BD65919AD )
term.note: The term "cycle-speed vehicle" is allowed but the preferred term follows a logical progression of levels.
term.example: mountain bicycle

term.name: moderate vehicle speed
term.definition: speed of a vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) that exceeds moderately-low vehicle speeds ( REF id4C7E8BE05FA745b0B15099A2733D5D72 ) but does not reach free-flow motorway speeds
term.note: Local regulations for the exact speed range vary.
term.example: A speed in the range of 48 km/h and 87 km/h.

term.name: moderately high vehicle speed
term.definition: speed of a vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) that is typical of free-flow motorway speeds to twice that speed
term.note: Local regulations for the exact speed range vary.
term.example: A speed in the range of 87 km/h and 198 km/h.

term.name: moderately high-speed vehicle
term.definition: vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) with a design speed ( REF id94141E56EA294dfb8212E7FA5553D1F6 ) in the range of moderately-high vehicle speeds ( REF idDB835A76111749c1883F689D46CC7CBF )
term.example: typical passenger car

term.name: moderately low vehicle speed
term.definition: speed of a vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) that exceeds speeds typical of pedal cycles but can be reached on performance pedal cycles in short bursts or by performance riders
term.note: Local regulations for the exact speed range vary.
term.example: SAE J3194:2019 associates this with a top speed in the range between 32 km/h and 48 km/h.

term.name: moderately low-speed vehicle
term.definition: vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) with a design speed ( REF id94141E56EA294dfb8212E7FA5553D1F6 ) in the range of moderately-low vehicle speeds ( REF id4C7E8BE05FA745b0B15099A2733D5D72 )
term.example: typical moped

term.name: moderate-speed vehicle
term.definition: vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) with a design speed ( REF id94141E56EA294dfb8212E7FA5553D1F6 ) in the range of moderate vehicle speeds ( REF id4872741586D64a2183735162D83FA308 )
term.example: typical side-by-side utility task vehicle (UTV)

term.name: ultra-low vehicle speed
term.definition: speed of a vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) that does not greatly exceed typical pedestrian speeds
term.note: Local regulations for the exact speed range vary.
term.example: SAE J3194:2019 associates this with a top speed of less than 13 km/h.

term.name: ultra-low-speed vehicle
term.definition: vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) with a design speed ( REF id94141E56EA294dfb8212E7FA5553D1F6 ) that does not exceed ultra-low vehicle speeds ( REF idF8EB867A8B6E4325B76F49E87B1DF605 )
term.note: The term "pedestrian speed vehicle" is allowed but the preferred term follows a logical progression of levels.

figure.name: Vehicle type - environment terms

term.name: motor vehicle
term.definition: motorized ( REF idDF73937CAFBE46b5BDE07EA77D115A61 ) road vehicle ( REF idCD96217608B748ad8F85A3F4059FD426 ) allowed to operate in the same driving spaces as motorized passenger cars

term.name: motorized vehicle
term.definition: self-propelled vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A )

term.name: non-road cycle
term.definition: human-powered vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) not meeting the legal requirements to be driven in cycle lanes ( REF idBE5E40CDEC8846b49D1CE99547F20B51 )

term.name: non-road vehicle
term.definition: vehicle not meeting the legal requirements to be driven in traffic lanes ( REF id1240152ED5B6429eA0A4B380F1D798E4 ) or cycle lanes ( REF idBE5E40CDEC8846b49D1CE99547F20B51 ) of a road network ( REF idEF0DB12C0BE247319EF2AC75AC234F8F )

term.name: road cycle
term.definition: vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) meeting the legal requirements to operate in cycle lanes ( REF idBE5E40CDEC8846b49D1CE99547F20B51 ) and cycleways ( REF idC2EE18B8A32D48a0AA257E98F7AED48E )
term.note: In some countries, other special lanes could also be open to road cycles, such as bus lanes.

term.name: road vehicle
term.definition: vehicle ( REF id555BFAB2A747457fB01D99511FDE885A ) meeting the requirements to operate within the driving space ( REF id3F880EDEBFE84014A43B46167936F4B1 ) of a road ( REF id72937CE094414775B90C995DFCB64EEB )
term.note: al entity

entry.name: fleet and freight management central system
maintenance and construction central management system
